results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

results.description:
David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) only ran for one season, but it became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience, where nyurulypa (good tricks) are used to keep wrecked cars on the red—sand roads of outback Australia. The cast use mulga wood, spinifex and clever hacks to showcase their ingenious approach to mechanics.

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.

“The core of Bush Mechanics was basically a road trip, where you had the crappest car in the world, and things would inevitably go wrong… so you have to innovate… things like stuffing a flat tyre with spinifex… or getting a tree and carving it to make a crankshaft. It became like a cult classic. It took the country, in a very quiet way, by storm.” – Rachel Perkins

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.

results.title: Since I Left You – The Avalanches
results.brief_description: Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling, The Avalanches’ ‘Since I Left You’ manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.

constellations_primary.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_primary.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

results.description: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.
description_for_label: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.

results.title: Red stone dancer: Henri Gaudier Brzeska
results.brief_description: A study of one of Gaudier-Brzeska’s most important sculptures, seen in different aspects of movement and light. The structure of the film is based on the characteristics found in a roll of film offcuts: random rhythms, interrupted movements, repeated movements, and the image relationships created by those movements and the static shots. Electronic sound track devised by Arthur Cantrill.

results.title: Eikon
results.brief_description: An experimental film with triple image effects done in the camera using a matte-box. The central image was filmed after the two side sections - the side sections being shot in a random way and no record kept of the various shots. Colour filters were used with the camera and not in the laboratory. The subject reminded the filmmakers of faces and figures in old icons, the triptych structure of the images also echoes the icon. An interesting blend of stillness, movement, rocks, flesh, woman, girl, water, sky, colour, light, wind, sun and foliage.

results.title: 4000 frames
results.brief_description: An ‘eye opener’ film experiment, this is a single frame film where every frame is discontinuous with the preceding frame. An attempt was made to avoid any type of relationship between frames whether of images, shapes and forms or association of ideas. The film sets out to investigate the way in which we can ‘read’ the content of single frames, when the frames are presented under varying conditions. Some of the images have been carefully composed, while others filmed simply as found objects.

results.title: Faces 1976–1996
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white, silent
results.brief_description:
In “Faces 1976–1996”, Sue Ford returned to the subjects of her seminal 1970s work “Faces” twenty years later. In collaboration with her son Ben Ford, the artist filmed her friends in the same format, framed in close-up with the camera trained on them for 25 seconds each, and presented the images in a multi-channel installation. Reflecting the artist’s interest in the camera’s ability to capture time, “Faces 1976–1996” shows the effect of time and change, and reveals the striking differences and inherent sameness on a person’s countenance.

Participants include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.brief_description: A social commentary on the environment in the year 3000 with a look back into the past and what used to be before the thoughtless destruction by humanity of the earth’s forests. 3-D computer animation with music soundtrack - no commentary.
